What is the definition of material equivalence or the biconditional?
Material equivalence or the biconditional is true when the atomic propositions share the same truth value, and false when their values differ.

p q ~p ⋅ ~q ~(p v qT T      F  F  F      F  T T F      F  F  T      F  T F T      T  F  F      F  T F F      T  T  T      T  F  Again, as you can see from the truth table, the truth values under the main operators of each sentence are identical on every row (i.e., for every assignment of truth values to the atomic propositions). In fact, there is a fifth truth functional connective called “material equivalence” or the “biconditional” that is defined as true when the atomic propositions share the same truth value, and false when the truth values different. Although we will not be relying on the biconditional, I provide the truth table for it below.
